docs.lead_paragraph: There is a gentleman to whom we incline, a Mexican, by name Don AMBROSIO ARMIJO. That is about all we know of him, except one other fact, to wit: that being nominated for the appointment of Delegate to represent the Territory of New-Mexico, he peremptorily declined.

headline.main: THE CRYSTAL PALACE.; Articles Contributed from Various Nations. FRENCH DEPARTMENT. IRISH DEPARTMENT. SAMUEL MARSHALL, Esq., Superintending Agent. ITALIAN DEPARTMENT. SIGNOR CORGHI, Superinteading Agent. The Sardinian States. The Lombard Venetian Kingdom. Duchy of Modena.

headline.main: THE PRESIDENT'S TOUR.; SPLENDID BANQUET AT PHILADELPHIA. Speeches of the President and Members of his Cabinet. Demonstrations on the Route through New-Jersey. RECEPTION AT NEWARK. Telegraphic. Arrangements for the Day.

docs.lead_paragraph: In the DAILY TIMES of yesterday morning, we gave an account of the President's official reception at Independence Hall, in Philadelphia, with a report of the speech which he made on that occasion. After this was concluded, the President, and the members of the Cabinet accompanying him, reached his quarters at the Merchants' Hotel, on Fourth-street, shortly after 7 o'clock, P. M.

byline.original: FROM THE SPECIAL REPORTERS OF THE DAILY TIMES

headline.main: LATEST INTELLIGENCE; By Telegraph to the New-York Daily Times. Appointments--Ex-President Tyler's Health--Who is willing to go to England, if Buchanan Backs Down?--A Sensible Man.

docs.lead_paragraph: PHILO WHITE, Esq., of Wisconsin, has been appointed Charge d'Affaires at Ecuador. Ex-President TYLER is sojourning at Old Point Comfort. His health is feeble, and he expects soon to visit the Mountains, under advice of his physicians.
docs.snippet: PHILO WHITE, Esq., of Wisconsin, has been appointed Charge d'Affaires at Ecuador. Ex-President TYLER is sojourning at Old Point Comfort. His health is feeble, and he expects soon to visit the Mountains, under advice of his physicians.

byline.original: Special Dispatch to the New-York Daily Times:

headline.main: THE PRESIDENT'S TOUR.; Visit of the President and Cabinet to New-York. Reception at Baltimore, Wilmington, and Philadelphia. Speeches of the President, Gen. Davis, Gen. Cushing, Mr. Guthrie and others. INCIDENTS ON THE ROUTE. FROM THE SPECIAL REPORTERS OF THE DAILY TIMES.

docs.lead_paragraph: We gave, in the DAILY TIMES of yesterday morning, full reports received by Telegraph of the enthusiastic welcome extended to the PRESIDENT on his arrival at Baltimore, and of the eloquent speech which he made in reply. The addresses of the members of his Cabinet were also briefly sketched, but we have since received full reports of them from our own Reporters.

headline.main: THE SOUTH.; Letters on the Production, Industry, and Resources of the Slabe States. NUMBER TWENTY-NINE.

docs.lead_paragraph: Visit to a Rice Plantation Continued. Mr. A has two rice plantations, a few miles apart, besides a large tract of forest land, reaching above the malarious district, in which there is a house for his overseer's family to retire to during the fever season.

byline.original: SPECIAL CORRESPONDENCE OF THE N. Y. DAILY TIMES

docs.lead_paragraph: PLYMOUTH CHURCH.--The recent deaths in Mr. BEECHER's family drew together an unusual number of persons at Plymouth Church, yesterday morning, expecting that the subject would be appropriately alluded to. They were not disappointed.
docs.snippet: PLYMOUTH CHURCH.--The recent deaths in Mr. BEECHER's family drew together an unusual number of persons at Plymouth Church, yesterday morning, expecting that the subject would be appropriately alluded to. They were not disappointed.

headline.main: FRANCE.; The Exhibition of Paintings--The Charivari and Mrs. Stowe--Incidents and Anecdotes--Paris Gossip.

docs.lead_paragraph: One of the late decrees of the Emperor meets with a good deal of opposition--that postponing the usual Exposition of Paintings of next year until 1855, and making the Gallery of that year a Universal one, to coincide with the Crystal Palace season.
docs.snippet: One of the late decrees of the Emperor meets with a good deal of opposition--that postponing the usual Exposition of Paintings of next year until 1855, and making the Gallery of that year a Universal one, to coincide with the Crystal Palace season.
